sections.title: What are we comparing?
sections.content:
Both **will** and **going to** can talk about the future, but we use them in different situations.

• **Will**: I will go, she will be, they will not (won't) come.
• **Going to**: I am going to go, she is going to be, they are not going to come.

The choice depends on whether we had a plan, made a decision at the moment of speaking, have present evidence, or are offering/promising.

sections.title: When to use GOING TO
sections.content:
Use **going to** when:

• You have already decided or planned: I'm going to study medicine. We're going to meet on Friday.
• You have an intention: She's going to buy a new car. They're going to move house.
• You predict something from present evidence (you can see or know something now): Look at those clouds – it's going to rain. He's going to fall! (He's on the ice.)
• Something is about to happen: The film is going to start in a minute.

Tip: If the plan or intention existed before the moment of speaking, use going to.

sections.title: When to use WILL
sections.content:
Use **will** when:

• You decide at the moment of speaking (spontaneous decision): I'll have a coffee. I'll help you with that.
• You offer, promise, or refuse: I'll pay for the tickets. I won't tell anyone. I won't do it.
• You make a general prediction (no present evidence): I think it will rain tomorrow. She'll probably be late.
• You talk about future facts: The meeting will be at 3 pm. The train will leave at 10.
• With think, hope, expect, probably, perhaps: I hope she will come. They'll probably agree.

Tip: If you just decided now, or you're offering/promising, use will.

sections.title: The difference between them
sections.content:
• **Plan or intention (already decided)** → going to: I'm going to see him tomorrow. (I already planned it.)
• **Decision at the moment of speaking** → will: The phone's ringing. – I'll get it. (I just decided now.)
• **Prediction with present evidence** (you can see it) → going to: She's pregnant – she's going to have a baby.
• **Prediction without present evidence** (guess, opinion) → will: I think he'll pass the exam.
• **Offer, promise, refusal** → will: I'll help you. I won't forget.

Same situation, different meaning: 'I'll go to the gym tomorrow' (decision now) vs 'I'm going to go to the gym tomorrow' (I already planned it).

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• Already planned / intention / prediction from what you see now → **going to** (am/is/are going to + verb).
• Just decided now / offer / promise / refusal / general prediction → **will** (will/won't + verb).
• When in doubt: plan or evidence now = going to; spontaneous or voluntary = will.

sections.title: Typical Czech learner errors
sections.content:
Czech often uses the present tense or one future form where English distinguishes will and going to:

• Using **will** for a plan you already made: Wrong: I will meet her tomorrow. (if you already arranged it) Right: I'm going to meet her tomorrow.
• Using **going to** for a spontaneous decision: Wrong: (Phone rings) I'm going to get it. Right: I'll get it.
• Using **will** when there is clear present evidence: Wrong: Look at the sky – it will rain. Right: Look at the sky – it's going to rain.
• Using **going to** for offers: Wrong: I'm going to help you. (sounds like a plan) Right: I'll help you. (offer now)

Tip: Ask yourself: Did I decide before now? (going to) Or am I deciding now / offering? (will)

questions.question: You already decided yesterday to see a film tonight. Which do you say?

options.a: I'm going to see a film tonight.
options.b: I will see a film tonight.

questions.question: The phone rings. You decide at that moment to answer it. Which do you say?
questions.explanation: Decision at the moment of speaking → will.

questions.question: You can see black clouds. You predict rain. Which is natural?
questions.explanation: Prediction based on present evidence (you can see the clouds) → going to.

questions.question: You want to offer to carry someone's bag. Which do you say?

options.b: I'm going to carry your bag.

questions.question: You have a general opinion about tomorrow's weather (no clouds now). Which is natural?

options.a: I think it's going to rain tomorrow.
options.c: I think it will rain tomorrow.
options.d: I think it will be raining tomorrow.

questions.explanation: General prediction (no present evidence), often with I think → will.

questions.question: I ____ (see) the dentist tomorrow at 10. (I already have an appointment.)
The phone's ringing. – I ____ (get) it.
questions.explanation: Decision at the moment of speaking → will.

questions.question: Look at those clouds – it ____ (rain).
questions.explanation: Prediction from present evidence → going to.

questions.question: I'm so tired. I ____ (have) a rest. (I just decided.)
She ____ (study) law at university. (She decided last year.)
That bag looks heavy. I ____ (carry) it for you.
We ____ (meet) at 6. (We arranged it yesterday.)
I think the match ____ (be) exciting.
He's running towards the bus but it's leaving – he ____ (miss) it.
questions.explanation: Prediction from what we can see now → going to.

questions.question: I promise I ____ (not tell) anyone.
They ____ (buy) a new car next year. (They've been saving for it.)
I don't think she ____ (come) to the party.

errorcorrection.title: Practice: Correct the form (will vs going to)

questions.question: Wrong: 'I will meet John at 5.' (You already arranged it.) Correct the sentence.
answers: I'm going to meet John at 5.
I am going to meet John at 5.
I'm going to meet John at 5
I am going to meet John at 5

questions.question: Wrong: (Phone rings) 'I'm going to get it.' (You decide at that moment.) Correct the sentence.
Wrong: 'Look at the sky – it will rain.' (You can see the clouds.) Correct the sentence.
answers: Look at the sky – it's going to rain.
Look at the sky – it is going to rain.
Look at the sky – it's going to rain
Look at the sky – it is going to rain
questions.explanation: Prediction from present evidence → going to.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I'm going to help you.' (You are offering now.) Correct the sentence.
Wrong: 'I think it's going to be sunny tomorrow.' (No special evidence, just your guess.) Correct the sentence.
answers: I think it will be sunny tomorrow.
I think it'll be sunny tomorrow.
I think it will be sunny tomorrow
I think it'll be sunny tomorrow
questions.explanation: General prediction with I think → will. (Going to is also possible but will is more common for a simple guess.)

questions.question: Wrong: 'She will study in Prague.' (She decided and applied last month.) Correct the sentence.
answers: She's going to study in Prague.
She is going to study in Prague.
She's going to study in Prague
She is going to study in Prague
